<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level

CANDIDATE NAME

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 177, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 388, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 806, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 127, 87]]<|/det|>
# Data

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 106, 594, 120]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g=9.81 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 138, 640, 152]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c=3.00 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 170, 630, 183]]<|/det|>
elementary charge \(e=1.60 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 201, 630, 215]]<|/det|>
unified atomic mass unit \(1 \mathrm{u}=1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 233, 630, 247]]<|/det|>
rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}}=1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 264, 630, 278]]<|/det|>
rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}}=9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{~kg}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 295, 650, 310]]<|/det|>
Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}}=6.02 \times 10^{23} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 327, 640, 341]]<|/det|>
molar gas constant \(R=8.31 \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1} \mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 358, 650, 372]]<|/det|>
Boltzmann constant \(k=1.38 \times 10^{-23} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~K}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 389, 690, 403]]<|/det|>
gravitational constant \(G=6.67 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{~N} \mathrm{~m}^{2} \mathrm{~kg}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 420, 650, 435]]<|/det|>
permittivity of free space \(\varepsilon_{0}=8.85 \times 10^{-12} \mathrm{~F} \mathrm{~m}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 437, 650, 466]]<|/det|>
\[\left(\frac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}}\right)=8.99 \times 10^{9} \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{~F}^{-1})\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 482, 636, 495]]<|/det|>
Planck constant \(h=6.63 \times 10^{-34} \mathrm{~J} \mathrm{~s}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 513, 686, 527]]<|/det|>
Stefan-Boltzmann constant \(\sigma=5.67 \times 10^{-8} \mathrm{~W} \mathrm{~m}^{-2} \mathrm{~K}^{-4}\)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 570, 171, 580]]<|/det|>
# Formulae

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 602, 583, 616]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion \(s=ut+\frac {1}{2}at^{2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 618, 580, 637]]<|/det|>
\[\nu ^{2}=u^{2}+2as\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 653, 552, 667]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure \(\Delta p=\rho g\Delta h\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 684, 542, 698]]<|/det|>
upthrust \(F=\rho gV\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 720, 560, 750]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves \(f_{0}=\frac {f_{s}\nu }{\nu \pm \nu _{s}}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 765, 560, 779]]<|/det|>
electric current \(I=Anvq\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 796, 608, 810]]<|/det|>
resistors in series \(R=R_{1}+R_{2}+...\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 826, 613, 850]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel \(\frac {1}{R}=\frac {1}{R_{1}}+\frac {1}{R_{2}}+...\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 144, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 652, 91]]<|/det|> 1 (a) Explain what is meant by the accuracy of a measured value. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 168, 144, 185]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 168, 839, 184]]<|/det|> (b) Two solid cubes, A and B, are measured to determine the density of their materials. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 199, 546, 215]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 shows the measurements for cube A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 228, 540, 244]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 259, 645, 343]]<|/det|>
quantitymeasurement
length of side(1.53 ± 0.01) cm
mass(31.3 ± 0.5) g
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 358, 185, 375]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 356, 826, 374]]<|/det|> (i) Show that the calculated density of the material of cube A is \(8.7 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 510, 144, 527]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 510, 824, 527]]<|/det|> (ii) Calculate the percentage uncertainty in the density of the material of cube A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 694, 918, 712]]<|/det|>
percentage uncertainty = \(\%\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 725, 180, 742]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 725, 845, 742]]<|/det|> (iii) The density of the material of cube B is determined to be \(9.2 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3} \pm 6 \%\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 756, 898, 774]]<|/det|> State and explain whether cube A and cube B could be made from the same material.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 76, 144, 93]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 415, 91]]<|/det|>
2 (a) State the principle of moments.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 198, 144, 215]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 197, 918, 230]]<|/det|>
(b) A solid plastic cylinder floats in water. It is used to support one end of a horizontal uniform beam AB as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 240, 863, 523]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[410, 540, 590, 558]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 571, 918, 603]]<|/det|>
The beam has length 6.0 m and weight 1700 N . The beam is attached to solid ground with a hinge at end A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 618, 918, 666]]<|/det|>
The cylinder is floating vertically in the water. The top of the cylinder is attached at its centre to the beam at a horizontal distance of 5.0 m from end A . The cylinder applies a vertical force of 1300 N to the beam.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 680, 618, 697]]<|/det|>
A person of weight 660 N stands on the beam at point P .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 712, 410, 728]]<|/det|>
The beam AB is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 743, 185, 760]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 742, 770, 759]]<|/det|>
(i) By taking moments about end A , determine the distance \(x\) from A to P .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 912, 918, 929]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(ii) The bottom of the cylinder is submerged in the water to depth \(y\) as shown in Fig. 2.2. The beam is still attached to the cylinder but not shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 116, 700, 355]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 371, 590, 389]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 403, 918, 435]]<|/det|>
The cylinder has mass 11 kg and diameter 0.78 m . The beam exerts a vertical force of 1300 N on the cylinder. The cylinder is in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 448, 650, 465]]<|/det|>
Show that the upthrust acting on the cylinder is 1400 N .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 588, 191, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 588, 477, 605]]<|/det|>
(iii) The water has density \(990 \mathrm{~kg} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 619, 377, 636]]<|/det|>
Calculate the depth \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 820, 918, 838]]<|/det|>
<form>\(y=\) m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 191, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iv)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 74, 612, 91]]<|/det|>
(iv) The person can stand anywhere between A and B.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 106, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.3, sketch the variation of the depth of the bottom of the cylinder with the distance of the person from A, for distances between 0 and 6.0 m . Numerical values are not required.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[240, 165, 762, 508]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 526, 532, 543]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 74, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
3 (a) A truck R of mass 9400 kg moves with constant acceleration in a straight line down a slope, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 116, 727, 303]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 323, 532, 339]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 352, 918, 384]]<|/det|>
At point A the speed of the truck is \(13 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and at point B the speed of the truck is \(22 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). A and B are a distance of 180 m apart.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 400, 185, 416]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 400, 656, 416]]<|/det|>
(i) Calculate the acceleration of the truck between A and B .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 551, 918, 568]]<|/det|>
<form>acceleration = \(\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 584, 188, 600]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 584, 740, 600]]<|/det|>
(ii) Determine the gain in kinetic energy of the truck between A and B .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 801, 918, 818]]<|/det|>
<form>gain in kinetic energy = J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
(b) A short time after passing point B truck R moves in a straight line on horizontal ground. The driver of the truck applies the brakes. Fig. 3.2 shows the variation with time of the momentum of the truck.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 133, 816, 514]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 532, 534, 548]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 564, 185, 580]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 564, 304, 579]]<|/det|>
(i) Define force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 657, 188, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 655, 918, 687]]<|/det|>
(ii) Show that the average resultant force \(F\) acting on truck \(R\) between time \(t=0\) and \(t=15 \mathrm{~s}\) is \(-1.2 \times 10^{4} \mathrm{~N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 188, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(iii) An identical truck \(S\) has the same initial momentum as truck \(R\). Truck \(S\) experiences a constant force equal to the force \(F\) in (b)(ii).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 121, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether truck \(S\) will take more, less or the same amount of time to come to rest as truck \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
4 A device containing a microwave emitter and receiver is placed in front of a large metal sheet in a vacuum as shown in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 116, 724, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[413, 319, 590, 336]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 349, 918, 382]]<|/det|>
The line XY is perpendicular to the metal sheet. The device emits microwaves of frequency 6.3 GHz .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 396, 144, 413]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 395, 918, 428]]<|/det|>
(a) When the device is at position P , a stationary wave is formed between the device and the sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 441, 839, 459]]<|/det|>
Explain how the stationary wave, including the nodes and the antinodes, is formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 750, 144, 767]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 750, 180, 767]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 750, 564, 767]]<|/det|>
(b) (i) Calculate the wavelength of the microwaves.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 188, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 74, 821, 91]]<|/det|>
(ii) At point P the receiver detects a maximum amplitude of the stationary wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 106, 918, 150]]<|/det|>
The device is moved slowly from point P along the line XY and the receiver detects a series of minimum and maximum amplitudes. The first time a minimum amplitude is detected by the receiver is when the device is at point Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 167, 542, 183]]<|/det|>
Determine the distance between P and Q .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[495, 259, 918, 275]]<|/det|>
<form>distance = m 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 291, 188, 307]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 291, 918, 336]]<|/det|>
(iii) The intensity of the microwaves emitted by the device is increased. The frequency of the microwaves is unchanged. The device is moved slowly along the line XY from point Q until the next maximum amplitude is detected at point R .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 352, 918, 382]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the distance QR is greater than, less than or the same as distance PQ .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
5 A stationary loudspeaker emits sound of constant frequency. A microphone is placed near to the loudspeaker and connected to a cathode-ray oscilloscope (CRO). The trace on the screen of the CRO is shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 768, 497]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[466, 515, 530, 532]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 545, 555, 562]]<|/det|>
The time-base of the CRO is set to \(5.0 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{~s} \mathrm{~cm}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 577, 144, 594]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 575, 686, 594]]<|/det|>
(a) The speed of the sound emitted by the loudspeaker is \(330 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 607, 487, 624]]<|/det|>
Determine the wavelength of the sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 725, 918, 742]]<|/det|>
<form>wavelength = m

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 756, 144, 773]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 755, 918, 787]]<|/det|>
(b) The loudspeaker now moves in a straight line while emitting the same sound of constant frequency. The period of the trace on the CRO increases continuously.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 801, 487, 817]]<|/det|>
Describe the motion of the loudspeaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 641, 91]]<|/det|>
6 A cylindrical copper wire P of length 0.24 m is shown in Fig. 6.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[343, 102, 655, 225]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 240, 590, 256]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 271, 390, 286]]<|/det|>
The current in the wire is 0.85 A .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 287, 420, 302]]<|/det|>
The resistance of the wire is \(3.3 \mathrm{~m} \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 301, 635, 317]]<|/det|>
The total number of charge carriers \(N\) in the wire is \(2.6 \times 10^{22}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 317, 460, 333]]<|/det|>
The resistivity of copper is \(1.8 \times 10^{-8} \Omega \mathrm{~m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 349, 144, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 348, 709, 365]]<|/det|>
(a) Calculate the potential difference between the two ends of the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 438, 918, 456]]<|/det|>
<form>potential difference = V 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 472, 144, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 472, 185, 489]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 471, 709, 488]]<|/det|>
(b) (i) Show that the cross-sectional area of the wire is \(1.3 \times 10^{-6} \mathrm{~m}^{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 640, 144, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 640, 826, 657]]<|/det|>
(ii) Show that the number density of charge carriers in the wire is \(8.3 \times 10^{28} \mathrm{~m}^{-3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 781, 153, 797]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 780, 836, 797]]<|/det|>
(iii) Calculate the average drift speed of the charge carriers (electrons) in the wire.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 74, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
(c) A different copper wire Q has the same volume as wire P , but non-uniform radius, as shown in Fig. 6.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[337, 119, 660, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[408, 238, 590, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 268, 912, 285]]<|/det|>
The radius \(r_{1}\) at end X of wire Q is the same as the radius of wire P . Radius \(r_{2}\) is less than \(r_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 300, 185, 317]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 298, 905, 315]]<|/det|>
(i) State and explain how the resistance of wire Q compares with the resistance of wire P .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 75, 180, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 74, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
(ii) On Fig. 6.3, sketch a graph of the variation of the average drift speed of the charge carriers with distance from end X of wire Q.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[243, 118, 752, 375]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[464, 394, 533, 411]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 99, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 74, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
7 An isolated stationary nucleus \(Q\) decays into nucleus \(R\) and an \(\alpha\)-particle. The \(\alpha\)-particle has speed \(1.5 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 121, 144, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 120, 465, 138]]<|/det|>
(a) Complete the equation for this decay.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 147, 630, 190]]<|/det|>
\[
\boxed{88} \mathrm{~Q} \longrightarrow \boxed{222} \mathrm{~R} \longrightarrow \boxed{4} \alpha
\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 230, 144, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 229, 787, 247]]<|/det|>
(b) By considering momentum, calculate the speed of nucleus \(R\) after the decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[514, 396, 918, 415]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = \(\mathrm{ms}^{-1}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 430, 144, 447]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 429, 641, 447]]<|/det|>
(c) State three quantities that are conserved during the decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 460, 134, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 490, 134, 507]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 520, 134, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>
